org.azeckoski.reflectutils
Class ReflectUtils

java.lang.Object
  org.azeckoski.reflectutils.ReflectUtils

public class ReflectUtils
extends Object

Reflection utilities and utilities related to working with classes and their fields

These are built to be compatible with Apache Commons BeanUtils and the nesting structure works the same, refer to the apache BeanUtils project docs for details

Handles field operations for properties (getters and setters), partial properties (only getter or only setter), and fields. This improves upon the BeanUtils limitation of handling only properties or the Google utilities limitation of handling only fields.

Getting and setting fields supports simple, nested, indexed, and mapped values
Simple: Get/set a field in a bean (or map), Example: "title", "id"
Nested: Get/set a field in a bean which is contained in another bean, Example: "someBean.title", "someBean.id"
Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

Includes support for dealing with annotations and working with field which have annotations on them. Methods for finding fields with an annotation and finding all annotations in a class or on a fields are included.
Includes support for deep cloning, deep copying, and populating objects using auto-conversion. Also includes support for fuzzy copies where object data can be copied from one object to another without the objects being the same type.

Also includes an extendable conversion system for converting between java types. This system also handles conversions between arrays, maps, collections, and scalars and improves upon the apache system by handling more types and handling object holders.

Support for construction of any class and a set of utilities for determining what types of objects you are working with are also included. A method for executing a specific constructor can be used if more control if needed.
The utilities cache reflection data for high performance operation but uses weak/soft caching to avoid holding open ClassLoaders and causing the caches to exist in memory permanently. The ability to override the caching mechanism with your own is supported.

The utilities are modular and are meant to be extendable and overridable. All methods are protected or public so that the various utility classes can be easily overridden if needed.

Author:
Aaron Zeckoski (azeckoski@gmail.com)

 boolean isSingleton()

 Map<String,Object> map(Object object, int maxDepth, String[] fieldNamesToSkip, boolean ignoreNulls, boolean ignoreTransient, String initialKey)
          This handles the cloning of objects to maps, it is recursive and is a deep operation which traverses the entire object and clones every part of it, when converting to a map this will ensure that there are no objects which are not part of java.lang or java.util in the new map
NOTE: This can handle simple objects (non-maps and non-beans) but will have to make up the initial map key in the returned map, "data" will be used as the key
NOTE: Nulls are allowed to pass through this method (i.e. passing in a null object results in a null output)
static boolean pdNameCompare(String name, String fieldName)
          This is necessary because of the stupid capitalization rules used by Sun
 List<String> populate(Object object, Map<String,Object> properties)
          Populates an object with the values in the properties map, this will not fail if the fieldName in the map is not a property on the object or the fieldName cannot be written to with the value in the object.
 List<String> populateFromParams(Object object, Map<String,String[]> params)
          Populates an object with the String array values in the params map, this will not fail if the fieldName in the map is not a property on the object or the fieldName cannot be written to with the value in the object
Arrays which are length 1 will be converted to a string before they are set on the target field

ReflectUtils

public ReflectUtils(ClassFields.FieldFindMode fieldFindMode,
                    Map<Class<?>,ClassFields> reflectionCache,
                    Resolver resolver,
                    Map<Class<?>,Converter<?>> converters)
Create a new copy of the reflection utilities so you can control various things like the field finding mode and the caching
WARNING: This is expensive and recreating it over and over is not a good idea, you should use the static instance if you are not prepared to cache this object somewhere
Use getInstance() to avoid recreating this over and over

Parameters:
fieldFindMode - (optional) see ClassFields.FieldFindMode enum for details, null for default
reflectionCache - (optional) a cache for holding class cache data (implements map), null to use the default internal cache
resolver - (optional) the field path name resolver to use when resolving EL style paths, null for default
converters - (optional) a map of converters to add to the default set, null to use the default set

WARNING: changing modes will clear the existing cache

Parameters:
fieldFindMode - see ClassFields.FieldFindMode enum for details, null for default
See Also:
ClassFields.FieldFindMode

setReflectionCache

public void setReflectionCache(Map<Class<?>,ClassFields> reflectionCache)
Set the cache to be used for holding the reflection data, this allows control over where the reflection caches are stored, this should store the data in a way that it will not hold open the classloader the class comes from
Note that you can set this to a map implementation which does not store anything to disable caching if you like

Parameters:
reflectionCache - a cache for holding class cache data (implements map), null to use the default internal cache

public void setIncludeClassField(boolean includeClassField)
Set the option to include the "class" field when reflecting over objects, the default for this is false (do not include)

includeClassField - if true then include the value from the "getClass()" method as "class" when encoding beans and maps

analyzeClass

public <T> ClassFields<T> analyzeClass(Class<T> beanClass)
Analyze a class and produce an object which contains information about it and its fields

Type Parameters:
T -
Parameters:
beanClass - any object class
Returns:
the ClassFields analysis object which contains the information about this object class
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if class is null or primitive

constructClass

public <T> T constructClass(Class<T> beanClass)
Construct an object for the class of the given type regardless of whether it has a default constructor, this will construct anything which has a valid class type including primitives, arrays, collections and even classes without default constructors, this will attempt to use the default constructor first if available though. It must be possible to construct the class without knowing something about it beforehand, (i.e. classes with only constructors which require non-null arguments will not be able to be constructed)

Type Parameters:
T -
Parameters:
beanClass - any object class
Returns:
the newly constructed object of the given class type (if primitive then a wrapped object will be returned which java will unwrap automatically)

getFieldValue

public Object getFieldValue(Object object,
                            String fieldName)
Get the value of a field or property (getter method) from an object
Getting fields supports simple, nested, indexed, and mapped values:
Simple: Get/set a field in a bean (or map), Example: "title", "id"
Nested: Get/set a field in a bean which is contained in another bean, Example: "someBean.title", "someBean.id"
Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

Parameters:
object - any object
fieldName - the name of the field (property) to get the value of or the getter method without the "get" and lowercase first char
Throws:
FieldnameNotFoundException - if this fieldName does not exist on the object
IllegalArgumentException - if a failure occurs while getting the field value

getFieldValue

public Object getFieldValue(Object object,
                            String fieldName,
                            Class<? extends Annotation> annotationClass)
Get the value of a field or getter method from an object allowing an annotation to override
Getting fields supports simple, nested, indexed, and mapped values:
Simple: Get/set a field in a bean (or map), Example: "title", "id"
Nested: Get/set a field in a bean which is contained in another bean, Example: "someBean.title", "someBean.id"
Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

Parameters:
object - any object
fieldName - the name of the field (property) to get the value of or the getter method without the "get" and lowercase first char
annotationClass - if the annotation class is set then we will attempt to get the value from the annotated field or getter method first
Returns:
the value of the field OR null if the value is null
Throws:
FieldnameNotFoundException - if this fieldName does not exist on the object and no annotation was found
IllegalArgumentException - if a failure occurs while getting the field value

Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

setFieldValue

public void setFieldValue(Object object,
                          String fieldName,
                          Object value)
Set the value on the object field or setter method, will convert if needed
Setting fields supports simple, nested, indexed, and mapped values:
Simple: Get/set a field in a bean (or map), Example: "title", "id"
Nested: Get/set a field in a bean which is contained in another bean, Example: "someBean.title", "someBean.id"
Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

Parameters:
object - any object
fieldName - the name of the field (property) to set the value of or the setter method without the "set" and lowercase first char
value - the value to set on this field, must match the type in the object (will not attempt to covert)
Throws:
FieldnameNotFoundException - if the fieldName could not be found in this object
UnsupportedOperationException - if the value could not be converted to the field type
IllegalArgumentException - if the params are null or other failures occur setting the value

setFieldValue

public void setFieldValue(Object object,
                          String fieldName,
                          Object value,
                          boolean autoConvert)
Sets a value on the field of an object and will attempt to convert the property if configured to do so
Setting fields supports simple, nested, indexed, and mapped values:
Simple: Get/set a field in a bean (or map), Example: "title", "id"
Nested: Get/set a field in a bean which is contained in another bean, Example: "someBean.title", "someBean.id"
Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

Parameters:
object - any object
fieldName - the name of the field (property) to set the value of or the setter method without the "set" and lowercase first char
value - the value to set on this field, does not have to match the type in the object, the type will be determined and then we will attempt to convert this value to the type in the field
autoConvert - if true then automatically try to convert the value to the type of the field being set, otherwise only set the field if the value matches the type
Throws:
FieldnameNotFoundException - if the fieldName could not be found in this object
IllegalArgumentException - if the value type does not match the field type or the type could not be converted to the field type
UnsupportedOperationException - if the value could not be converted to the field type

type - any class
Returns:
a map of field name -> class type

Parameters:

filter - (optional) indicates the fields to return the types for, can be null for defaults

a map of field name -> class type

Parameters:
object - any object
Returns:
a map of name -> value
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if failures occur

getObjectValues

public Map<String,Object> getObjectValues(Object object,
                                          ClassFields.FieldsFilter filter,
                                          boolean includeClassField)
Get a map of all fieldName -> value and all getterMethodName -> value without the word "get" where the method takes no arguments, in other words, all values available from an object (readable values)

Parameters:
object - any object
filter - (optional) indicates the fields to return the values for, can be null for defaults
includeClassField - if true then the value from the "getClass()" method is returned as part of the set of object values with a type of Class and a field name of "class"
Returns:
a map of name -> value
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if failures occur

getFieldNameWithAnnotation

public String getFieldNameWithAnnotation(Class<?> elementClass,
                                         Class<? extends Annotation> annotationClass)
Find the getter field on a class which has the given annotation

Parameters:
elementClass - any class
annotationClass - the annotation type which is expected to be on the field
Returns:
the name of the field or null if no fields are found with the indicated annotation
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the annotation class is null

clone

public <T> T clone(T object,
                   int maxDepth,
                   String[] fieldNamesToSkip)
Deep clone an object and all the values in it into a brand new object of the same type, this will traverse the bean and will make new objects for all non-null values contained in the object

Type Parameters:
T -
Parameters:
object - any java object, this can be a list, map, array, or any simple object, it does not have to be a custom object or even a java bean, also works with DynaBeans
maxDepth - the number of objects to follow when traveling through the object and copying the values from it, 0 means to only copy the simple values in the object, any objects will be ignored and will end up as nulls, 1 means to follow the first objects found and copy all of their simple values as well, and so forth
fieldNamesToSkip - the names of fields to skip while cloning this object, this only has an effect on the bottom level of the object, any fields found on child objects will always be copied (if the maxDepth allows)
Returns:
the cloned object

copy

public void copy(Object orig,
                 Object dest,
                 int maxDepth,
                 String[] fieldNamesToSkip,
                 boolean ignoreNulls)
Deep copies one object into another, this is primarily for copying between identical types of objects but it can also handle copying between objects which are quite different, this does not just do a reference copy of the values but actually creates new objects in the current classloader

Parameters:
orig - the original object to copy from
dest - the object to copy the values to (must have the same fields with the same types)
maxDepth - the number of objects to follow when traveling through the object and copying the values from it, 0 means to only copy the simple values in the object, any objects will be ignored and will end up as nulls, 1 means to follow the first objects found and copy all of their simple values as well, and so forth
fieldNamesToSkip - the names of fields to skip while cloning this object, this only has an effect on the bottom level of the object, any fields found on child objects will always be copied (if the maxDepth allows)
ignoreNulls - if true then nulls are not copied and the destination retains the value it has, if false then nulls are copied and the destination value will become a null if the original value is a null
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the copy cannot be completed because the objects to copy do not have matching fields or types

map

public Map<String,Object> map(Object object,
                              int maxDepth,
                              String[] fieldNamesToSkip,
                              boolean ignoreNulls,
                              boolean ignoreTransient,
                              String initialKey)
This handles the cloning of objects to maps, it is recursive and is a deep operation which traverses the entire object and clones every part of it, when converting to a map this will ensure that there are no objects which are not part of java.lang or java.util in the new map
NOTE: This can handle simple objects (non-maps and non-beans) but will have to make up the initial map key in the returned map, "data" will be used as the key
NOTE: Nulls are allowed to pass through this method (i.e. passing in a null object results in a null output)

Parameters:
bean - any java object
maxDepth - the number of objects to follow when traveling through the object and copying the values from it, 0 means to only copy the simple values in the object, any objects will be ignored and will end up as nulls, 1 means to follow the first objects found and copy all of their simple values as well, and so forth
fieldNamesToSkip - the names of fields to skip while cloning this object, this only has an effect on the bottom level of the object, any fields found on child objects will always be copied (if the maxDepth allows)
ignoreNulls - if true then nulls are not copied and the destination retains the value it has, if false then nulls are copied and the destination value will become a null if the original value is a null
ignoreTransient - if true then all transient fields will be skipped, useful when serializing
initialKey - (optional) the initial key to use when converting simpler objects to maps
Returns:
the resulting map which contains the cloned data from the object

populate

public List<String> populate(Object object,
                             Map<String,Object> properties)
Populates an object with the values in the properties map, this will not fail if the fieldName in the map is not a property on the object or the fieldName cannot be written to with the value in the object. This will attempt to convert the provided object values into the right values to place in the object
NOTE: simple types like numbers and strings can almost always be converted from just about anything though they will probably end up as 0 or ""
Setting fields supports simple, nested, indexed, and mapped values:
Simple: Get/set a field in a bean (or map), Example: "title", "id"
Nested: Get/set a field in a bean which is contained in another bean, Example: "someBean.title", "someBean.id"
Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

Parameters:
object - any object
properties - a map of fieldNames -> Object
Returns:
the list of fieldNames which were successfully written to the object
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the arguments are invalid

populateFromParams

public List<String> populateFromParams(Object object,
                                       Map<String,String[]> params)
Populates an object with the String array values in the params map, this will not fail if the fieldName in the map is not a property on the object or the fieldName cannot be written to with the value in the object
Arrays which are length 1 will be converted to a string before they are set on the target field
Setting fields supports simple, nested, indexed, and mapped values:
Simple: Get/set a field in a bean (or map), Example: "title", "id"
Nested: Get/set a field in a bean which is contained in another bean, Example: "someBean.title", "someBean.id"
Indexed: Get/set a list/array item by index in a bean, Example: "myList[1]", "anArray[2]"
Mapped: Get/set a map entry by key in a bean, Example: "myMap(key)", "someMap(thing)"

Parameters:
object - any object
params - a map of fieldNames -> String[] (normally from an http request)
Returns:
the list of fieldNames which were successfully written to the object
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the arguments are invalid

convert

public <T> T convert(Object object,
                     Class<T> type)
Converts an object to any other object if possible

Type Parameters:
T -
Parameters:
object - any object
type - any class type that you want to try to convert the object to
Returns:
the converted value (allows null to pass through except in the case of primitives which become the primitive default)
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the conversion cannot be completed
See Also:
ConversionUtils.convert(Object, Class)

getSuperclasses

public static List<Class<?>> getSuperclasses(Class<?> clazz)
Returns:
a list of all superclasses and implemented interfaces by the supplied class, recursively to the base, up to but excluding Object.class. These will be listed in order from the supplied class, all concrete superclasses in ascending order, and then finally all interfaces in recursive ascending order.
This will include duplicates if any superclasses implement the same classes

Returns:
the class type contained in this collecion
